Award.AwardTitle: RCN: The Porphyra Genome: Promoting Resource Development and Integrative Research in Algal Genomics
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will promote studies of the genome of an economically important red alga, Porphyra ("nori", "laver"), which is a current sequencing project at the Joint Genome Institute (DOE). Analysis of the Porphrya genome will include comparative studies with genomes of closely related and derived groups (e.g., other red algae, green algae, dinoflagellates). The overall goal of this project is to establish a network of investigators whose members will provide the highest quality public dissemination of the Porphyra genome for use by researchers worldwide, while fostering new collaborations that will lead to experimental application of the genomic data. It is anticipated that RCN-aided use of the Porphyra genome will lead to new understanding of nuclear-organelle co-evolution, studies of nitrogen and carbon metabolism in photosynthetic organisms, comparative investigations of how multicellular complexity arose independently in different eukaryotic groups, and the generation of a wealth of new markers for studies in molecular evolution and systematics. The RCN will meet annually, with continued work among participants throughout the year. Each annual meeting will include formal bioinformatics training, evaluation of the overall quality of genome annotation, and research reports and discussions on cross-genomic and experimental applications of the genomic data. The RCN will include many students and postdoctoral fellows who will form a group of genomics-competent young researchers organized around central questions that will impact key societal needs including multitrophic aquaculture (e. g., bioremediation) and an integrated analysis of photosynthetic and photoprotective pigments as they affect carbon metabolism on our warming planet. The website will include genome-related lessons for K-12 and college instructors, and the RCN will sponsor public convocations and professional symposia that will present the many contributions of the genome project while highlighting the diversity of scientists engaged in this work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The research community established by this NSF Research Collaboration Network analyzed the nuclear genome of the marine red alga Porphyra umbilicalis (laver). The red algae are among the earliest evolving plants, and represent one of the most ancient multicellular lineages of eukaryotic organisms. Research findings included new information on genes involved in high light tolerance, cell wall formation, and several aspects of drying tolerance, all traits required to survive its intertidal habitat. Genomic studies added to understanding of this traditionally harvested human food, including nutritional aspects of vitamin (e.g., vitamin B12) and mineral (e.g., iron) acquisition.  The cytoskeleton, that part of the cell that is responsible for many aspects of cell division, intracellular transport, and cell communication, is encoded by fewer types of cytoskeletal genes in Porphyra and other red algae compared to other multicellular lineages (e.g., animals, land plants). This likely contributes to understanding why red algae tend to have smaller statures.   A new calcium-dependent sensor system, seemingly unique to red algae, was described. Comparative analyses of the genome of Porphyra umbilicalis to available genomes of other red algae and members of other eukaryotic lineages provided broader insights into eukaryotic evolution.

Broad Impacts

Few red algal genomes are available to the scientific community, despite the evolutionary, ecological, and commercial importance of the red algae. By providing a detailed analysis of the Porphyra umbilicalis genome (v.1.5) to the scientific community, many other scientists’ studies will be advanced.  The Porphyra Research Collaboration Network recruited and integrated graduate students, postdoctoral scientists, and senior scientists into an interdisciplinary team where female scientists represented nearly half of the membership, and some members were international participants, including scientists from four continents. This provided excellent training for U.S. graduate students and postdoctoral scientists.  Formal training of project members included workshops at project meetings on gene annotation, analysis of microbial components of host species, and of programming and statistical software.  In addition to peer-reviewed publication of the genome (v.1.5) and other scientific papers, the RCN produced an Annotation Manual (v.1.6). The RCN Annotation Manual (v.1.6) covers techniques for manual annotation of genes, and it is available at the newly public RCN blast site, Red Algal Resources to Promote Integrative Research in Algal Genomics (http://porphyra.rutgers.edu).
